question: [December 2024] Chrystia Freeland, the Minister of Finance, has resigned. She publishes her resignation letter which is harshly critical of Prime Minister Trudeau. Her resignation was prompted by an upcoming cabinet reshuffle in which Trudeau intended to install you as the new Finance Minister. The offer remains open. Do you accept Trudeau's offer and join his cabinet?

answers.answer: I will accept the position of Finance Minister. Our country is facing one of the most severe crises of its history. To get through it, we will need big changes. I can bring that change. It is my solemn duty to help Canada get through this crisis.
answers.feedback: Your addition to the cabinet rejuvenates the party but is unable to save Trudeau;s reputation. He resigns, and you are slightly tarnished for being in government with him for the short stint.

answers.answer: I will not join the Trudeau Cabinet. The Prime Minister is currently fighting through a political firestorm, and I can't risk getting caught up in it.
answers.feedback: Good call. The pressure on Trudeau continues to build, and he announces his resignation in the New Year.

question: [January 2025] Justin Trudeau has announced his resignation as Prime Minister and Liberal leader in the face of ever mounting pressure. You will run for leadership of the Liberal Party, but most Canadians are unfamiliar with you. How will you introduce yourself to Canadians?

answers.answer: If we are to win against Poilievre's Conservatives, we need to reach out and grow our tent. I will appear on Juno News and make my case to their conservative audience.
answers.feedback: The interview is extremely hostile. There;s no way you got any positive impression among their audience.

answers.answer: Canadians want a serious leader. That's why I will first be appearing in a CBC interview with Rosemary Barton. My command of the issues and policy will demonstrate that I am the most qualified person to be Prime Minister.
answers.feedback: The interview goes fairly well, but Barton is adversarial and does not give you an easy time.

answers.answer: I want to make clear my commitment to French Canadians by first appearing in an interview with Patrice Roy on Radio-Canada.
answers.feedback: Quebec appreciates you putting them first, but your weak French impedes your ability to communicate clearly.

answers.answer: I'm going to try something different. Instead of a political interview, I'll go on the Daily Show with Jon Stewart.
answers.feedback: Going on an American show nets you some derision, but many Canadians watch more American TV than Canadian, and this allows you to reach them.

question: [January 2025] United States President Donald Trump has floated the idea of Canada becoming the 51st American state. What do you make of it?

answers.answer: The bottom line is that it's not going to happen. We can cooperate on trade or on defence, but we do things differently here.
answers.feedback: This balances the need for a clear dismissal of the idea without further damaging Canada-US relations.

answers.answer: I support anything that promotes Canadian prosperity. Closer integration with the United States could benefit both our countries, and I would be interested in exploring that.
answers.feedback: This may appeal to some in your globalist bubble, but your supporters are outraged at the idea of integration with the Trumpian United States.

answers.answer: Mr. Trump often says outlandish things. They don't deserve a response.
answers.feedback: Trump continues to bring up the idea, and your supporters demand a strong response.

answers.answer: Trump is threatening our sovereignty as an independent nation. We cannot let it stand. If he continues on this path, we should reconsider our military cooperation and seek other allies.
answers.feedback: This is a strong answer, but risks escalating the situation.

question: [February 2025] President Trump has announced 25% tariffs on all Canadian products, which he justifies by claiming Canadian border enforcement is allowing "mass numbers of people to come in and fentanyl to come in". How do you respond?

answers.answer: These tariffs are a tax on American importers. That means American consumers will pay more for their food, their electricity, their gas, and other necessities. We should let Trump shoot himself in the foot.
answers.feedback: Workers in export industries are fearful of losing their jobs, and this does nothing to alleviate their fears.

answers.answer: We need to retaliate with dollar-for-dollar, targeted counter-tariffs. Trump is a bully, and we can't give him an inch otherwise he will come back asking for more.
answers.feedback: This helps you ride the wave of Canadian patriotism sweeping through the country.

answers.answer: This is an urgent threat to our economy. We need to do everything to address this issue, including targeted counter-tariffs, stronger border enforcement, and diversifying our trade partners.
answers.feedback: Canadians are happy to see you give this issue your full attention.

answers.answer: These tariffs would destroy our economy. We need to show Trump we are willing to work with him on the border and other issues.
answers.feedback: Caving to Trump makes you look weak, and tariffs end up going into effect anyway.

question: [February 2025] Brookfield Asset Management has decided to move its headquarters from Toronto to New York. You were chairman of the board for Brookfield. What was your involvement in this decision?

answers.answer: The decision was made after I quit my position as chair of the board to run for leadership. I no longer have any connection with Brookfield.
answers.feedback: Journalists retrieve company documents that show the decision was approved in October, long before you left the company. And you still own $1.7 million in Brookfield stock options.

answers.answer: We need a distraction from this. I'll put out some attacks on Poilievre for his lack of economic experience and his ties to elite circles.
answers.feedback: You;re dragging this race into the mud.

answers.answer: The changes reported are technical in nature, and with respect to jobs, Brookfield has clearly stated that Canadian operations were not impacted. This is a non-issue.
answers.feedback: Nevertheless, this still leaves Canadians feeling concerned.

question: [March 2025] What leverage does Canada have against the US for the upcoming trade war and negotiations?

answers.answer: We're their biggest supplier of semiconductors. We supply almost all their semiconductors. Everybody in the White House is a tech-bro except for Trump â€” they all need semiconductors, and they all come from Canada. Maybe one day they won't show up, we'll see.
answers.feedback: This would be a solid message, if it were true. Unfortunately, Canada is a relatively small exporter of semiconductors.

answers.answer: We're their biggest supplier of electricity, biggest supplier of fertilizer, biggest supplier of aluminium. They are dependent on us for trade, and we could consider putting some export restrictions.
answers.feedback: Aluminium and fertilizer producers are worried that they will pay the price for the trade war. However, this stance does make you look strong.

answers.answer: Trump always chickens out. We need to hold firm on our counter-tariffs, and he will come to the table. Just as he did in his first administration.
answers.feedback: This is a sensible response, but some are worried that this time is different.

answers.answer: We own a large amount of American treasury bonds. Hypothetically, if we were to sell them off, the American dollar could take a lot of damage.
answers.feedback: The insinuation appeals to your background as a banker.

question: [March 2025] As the Liberal leadership election nears its conclusion, what is your primary message to Liberal members?

answers.answer: I'll focus on my biography. I have managed economic crises, built strong economies, and run tough negotiations. I have the experience to lead in this crucial time.
answers.feedback: Your experience in both the public and private sectors sets you apart from your rivals.

answers.answer: I'll emphasize change. I will make clear that I want to turn the country around, distancing myself from Trudeau and his record.
answers.feedback: You;re leaning into an outsider image. This is refreshing to many, but may disappoint those who supported many of Trudeau;s reforms.

answers.answer: Laser focus on the economy. I will talk extensively about my detailed proposals for free trade within Canada, efficiency in the public service, and tax cuts for the middle class.
answers.feedback: Your focus on the economy synergizes with professional experience.

answers.answer: I will talk about the Liberal values that unite us. These values drive us to work toward social progress, to protect the environment, and to support each other. I will carry this Liberal torch to make Canada a shining example, from coast to coast to coast.
answers.feedback: This message has you leaning into a more progressive image.

question: [March 2025] Congratulations! You have been sworn in as the 24th Prime Minister of Canada. Your party is experiencing a rebound in the polls from the lows of the political crisis in December. You will call a snap election to capitalize on your fresh image and legitimize your position. However, you have a chance to enact some policies before heading into the election.

answers.answer: We don't have time for this. I will call the election immediately and hit the campaign trail. We have to strike while the iron is hot.
answers.feedback: Rushing into the election helps limit how much the Conservatives can spend out of their massive warchest as election spending limits kick in.

answers.answer: I will reverse the increase in the capital gains tax and abolish the consumer carbon tax.
answers.feedback: This ends two flagship policies of the Trudeau administration and undermines the Conservatives; messaging against you.

answers.answer: I will call Parliament back into session to send out $400 cheques to every Canadian to support families through the affordability crisis.
answers.feedback: Trudeau tried a similar policy a few months ago which contributed to the collapse of his government. Let;s hope Canadians appreciate this small financial help.

answers.answer: I will call Parliament back into session to approve funds to support workers who may lose their jobs because of the American tariffs.
answers.feedback: This move underscores your focus on trade issues.

question: [March 2025] With the federal election kicking off, what will be the main theme of your campaign?

answers.answer: Elbows up! Canada never, ever, will be part of America in any way, shape or form. Trump is trying to break us, so America can own us. But this is Canada. We decide what happens here. Never 51!
answers.feedback: This is a strong message that can help rally voters under your banner as Canadians become increasingly wary of the American threat.

answers.answer: Canada is not broken. But it does need experienced leadership and a real plan to ensure all Canadians benefit in an increasingly dangerous world. I've worked under Liberal and Conservative governments to deliver for Canadians, and I got the job done. Pierre Poilievre has been a politician his entire life and in that entire time, he hasn't fixed a thing.
answers.feedback: This does a good job of pitting your experience against that of Poilievre.

answers.answer: We need to lead with our values. That means protecting our system of universal healthcare. Protecting $10-a-day childcare. Protecting our pensions. Protecting the right to abortion.
answers.feedback: This appeals to your supporters, but don;t forget to also broaden your appeal.

answers.answer: I will focus on my plan for the economy. The Trudeau government did not put enough focus on the economy, and I will be different.
answers.feedback: You work tirelessly to renew voters; trust of the Liberal Party on the economy.

question: [March 2025] Where will you focus your effort as the campaign begins?

answers.answer: I will campaign in Ottawa and Montreal. These are must-win regions that we need to secure.
I'm heading to Vancouver. We can make some gains from the NDP there and lock down Surrey.
I'll go to Alberta and Saskatchewan to show them I'm serious about national unity.
I'm going to the Maritimes to win them back for the Liberal Party.

question: [March 2025] The Conservatives, led by Pierre Poilievre, have maintained a commanding lead in the polls for over a year. What will be your main angle of attack on the Conservative leader?

answers.answer: Pierre Poilievre is the type of politician who is a life long politician, worships the market, and sees opportunity in tragedy to push an agenda of cutting taxes and taking away the social safety net.
answers.feedback: This line of attack contrasts Poilievre;s experience (or lack thereof) with your own impressive qualifications.

answers.answer: I'm going to run a positive campaign and avoid mentioning Poilievre.
answers.feedback: Your advisors feel like you're leaving something on the table.

answers.answer: Mr. Poilievre is running on the same playbook as President Trump. You can't stand up to someone if you're using their playbook. Simple as that.
answers.feedback: Tying Poilievre with Trump is a good way of hurting his image.

answers.answer: Pierre Poilievre is weird. He refuses to get security clearance, shills for bitcoin, and disrespects political norms. And what's with all those three word slogans?
answers.feedback: This line of attack might play well on social media, but it doesn;t seem to move the needle on voting intentions. Meanwhile, Poilievre goes after your party over the cost-of-living.

question: [March 2025] As Canada is a bilingual country with a significant French-speaking minority, political leaders are expected to campaign in both official languages. However, your own French is rusty. To what extent will you campaign in French?

answers.answer: I will have all my campaign materials translated into French, but I will avoid speaking French any more than necessary.
answers.feedback: French Canadians feel snubbed that their language is not being accorded the equality supposedly enshrined by your party and the country.

answers.answer: I will put every effort into making my campaign bilingual. I will not hold back from speaking in French at rallies, even in English Canada. I will give as many French interviews as possible.
answers.feedback: French Canadians are glad you are making an effort. This does alienate some Anglos though.

answers.answer: I will prioritize making myself understood. That means speaking French and English in the respective communities. I will not hesitate to switch to English when I have difficulty expressing myself.
answers.feedback: This helps you get your message across, but some French Canadians still feel you could make a better effort.

question: [March 2025] The NDP, Bloc, and Greens compete with you for progressive voters. How will you deal with them?

answers.answer: I will ignore them as much as possible and run my own campaign. However, I will emphasize my progressive policies to draw their support.
answers.feedback: Some progressive voters are attracted by this, but you shed some moderates to the Conservatives.

answers.answer: I will make this election a personality battle between myself and Poilievre. I will hammer that Poilievre cannot be trusted to stand up to Trump. Our very sovereignty is at stake.
answers.feedback: Progressive voters flock to you driven by their fear of Trump.

answers.answer: I will eviscerate these so-called "progressive" parties for splitting the vote.
answers.feedback: This negativity turns many progressives away from considering your candidacy and gives more attention to the parties to your left.

answers.answer: We need to focus on winning over conservatives. I will criticize the class warfare type language prominent in much of progressive politics and avoid any discussion of inequality.
answers.feedback: Fair. Socialist-leaning voters are not pleased, but you don;t need them anyway.

question: [March 2025] How will you distinguish yourself from former Prime Minister Justin Trudeau?

answers.answer: I will distance myself from his social progressivism. I will abolish the ministerial post for Women and Equality, affirm that there are two genders and that only biological women should have access to women-only spaces, and criticize budgetary spending on progressive social causes.
answers.feedback: Your base is disappointed, and your own non-binary child is not happy with you.

answers.answer: I will criticize his administration wholesale to make clear our differences. His failed governance has given us a weak economy, soaring cost-of-living, and unsustainable immigration.
answers.feedback: This appeals to some but with criticisms this harsh, why were you his economic advisor?

answers.answer: We share values. But as Liberals, we must focus on both economic growth and fairness. Trudeau focused too much on one side of that equation. I will be different and will bring a laser focus on the economy.
answers.feedback: This balances distancing yourself from Trudeau on the main issue concerning Canadians while assuring the base you are still aligned with them.

answers.answer: There's not much I would have done differently. Of course, we're different people so I will bring certain sensibilities about the economy that Trudeau didn't have.
answers.feedback: This answer makes it easy for your opponents to criticize you as a continuation of the Trudeau government.

question: [March 2025] What will be your approach to media appearances?

answers.answer: I will go on any popular program that will have me. As a new face in politics, I need to introduce myself to as wide a range of people as possible.
answers.feedback: Some programs are virulently opposed to you and take the opportunity to dig into you. Additionally, some people criticize you for legitimizing outlets that are politically fringe despite their large audiences.

answers.answer: I will give all the usual interviews with the press. I'll also go on business-oriented podcasts and cultural media to make a wide appeal.
answers.feedback: This successfully gets your message to the usual crowds as well as reaching people who wouldn;t normally hear your message.

answers.answer: Canadians want a serious leader. I will only take interviews from established, journalistic, media organizations.
answers.feedback: Journalists are happy to be given somewhat exclusive access to you. However, you don;t reach audiences of alternative media.

answers.answer: I want to limit my media exposure. I will focus on campaigning and sticking to my rehearsed message.
answers.feedback: This is a safe approach, but you may be leaving something on the table.

question: [March 2025] You have recruited a number of "star" candidates to run under the Liberal banner. Is there any candidate you would like to highlight?

answers.answer: You want defenders of social justice like Nathalie Pronovost. Out of the tragedy of the shootings at Concordia, she became an activist and now she's running for us.
answers.feedback: She is a great candidate to highlight, but her name is Provost (not Pronovost), and she is a survivor of the Polytechnique massacre (not Concordia).

answers.answer: I will recruit Christy Clark to run in Fleetwood-Port Kells. She is a former Liberal premier from British Columbia, and as premier she embodied fiscal responsibility and pragmatic governance with five balanced budgets and strong economic growth.
answers.feedback: Her premiership was also characterized by rapidly rising inequality and cost-of-living. She remains fairly unpopular in much of BC, though her high-profile candidacy may help in Fleetwood-Port Kells.

answers.answer: I will highlight Gregor Robertson, a man with significant executive experience and vision. He was mayor of Vancouver for 10 years, served provincially in the BC NDP, and co-founded Happy Planet, an organic foods company. By the end of his mayoralty, Vancouver had the lowest unemployment in Canada, the most extensive bike network in North America, and became among the most livable cities in the world.
answers.feedback: Impressive as his record is, Robertson is also blamed by many for the exceedingly high housing costs in Vancouver which increased 150% during his tenure.

answers.answer: I will talk about Priti Obhrai-Martin, our candidate for Calgary East. She is the daughter of Deepak Obhrai, a life-long Conservative who held the riding for nearly 20 years. Our campaign is bringing people together and uniting our country. Together, we will build Canada strong.
answers.feedback: Calgary has been a Conservative stronghold forever. Hopefully she can make that change.

question: [March 2025] Aside from the official debates, TVA runs a French leaders' debate every election. Will you attend?

answers.answer: Why not? I will attend to show I do not fear confrontation.
answers.feedback: The pace and language of the debate leave you appearing out of your depth. Blanchet wins the debate and Poilievre has a strong performance.

answers.answer: I will refuse on the grounds that Pedneault, the Green party leader, was not invited.
answers.feedback: This is an odd reason seeing as the Greens are polling below 2%.

answers.answer: The network is charging $75,000 for my attendance. My campaign can easily pay for this, but I will refuse to attend on principle. Debates and media appearances should not be bought and sold, period.
answers.feedback: This makes sense seeing as this is the first time a network has charged the candidates to debate.

question: [March 2025] Reporting is coming out that Paul Chiang, the Liberal MP and candidate for Markham-Unionville, made a joke that suggested turning in a Conservative candidate over to the Chinese consulate in exchange for a bounty. He has apologized for the comment, calling it "deplorable". How will you handle this situation?

answers.answer: This was a terrible lapse of judgement on the part of Mr. Chiang. However, he has apologized, and I will take this as a teachable moment for him. He is a person of integrity with a quarter-century of service in his community, and I stand by his candidacy.
answers.feedback: The RCMP open an investigation into the event, and Paul Chiang chooses to resign his candidacy. Furthermore, Hong Kong diaspora groups are incensed by your defence of him.

answers.answer: I can't allow this to derail the campaign. I will quickly drop his candidacy for Markham-Unionville and nominate Peter Yuen instead.
answers.feedback: Paul Chiang understands and bows out gracefully. However, the media needle Peter Yuen for his ties to Chinese community organizations linked with the Chinese government.

answers.answer: I will defend Paul Chiang and argue that his joke, while of bad taste, has no bearing on his qualifications as an MP. He is an excellent legislator and representative for his community, and I stand by his candidacy.
answers.feedback: The RCMP open an investigation into the event, and Paul Chiang chooses to resign his candidacy. Furthermore, your lack of clear condemnation for his comment infuriates Hong Kong diaspora groups.

question: [April 2025] The economy is a major theme of this election. What will be your main economic message?

answers.answer: I have the experience it takes to make the right decisions on the economy. I will have a relentless focus on the economy and delivering for Canadians.
answers.feedback: Nice sentiment, but a little light on details. Voters want to know that you have a concrete plan.

answers.answer: We are masters in our own home. I have a plan for free trade within Canada and expediting major economic projects. I will also use public investments to catalyze private investment into building Canada strong.
answers.feedback: In these economically challenging times, this is what Canadians want to hear.

answers.answer: I will restore investor confidence in our economy. Regulations have grown too burdensome and taxes are too high. I will move quickly to simplify our regulatory regime and reduce taxes on business. I want investors everywhere to see Canada as the most attractive option.
answers.feedback: Your supporters are concerned about potential side effects and lost revenue. This boosts your image on Bay Street, however.

answers.answer: We need to invest in Canadians. The best way to boost productivity is by giving people the tools they need. By increasing funding for trade schools and universities, ensuring families have access to affordable childcare, and investing into transit, we can build a more prosperous Canada.
answers.feedback: This was Trudeau;s brand, and voters are tired of it.

question: [April 2025] While you were at Brookfield, most of the funds you managed were registered to a Bermuda address allowing the company to avoid $5.3 billion in taxes. Is this use of tax havens ethical?

answers.answer: I'm no longer with Brookfield and the company followed all the rules. Next question.
answers.feedback: Way to dodge the question.

answers.answer: I know how the world works. That gives me the ability to put in place all of the necessary rules to ensure that the appropriate taxes are paid here in Canada.
answers.feedback: You;re alluding to tax reform but without any details. Maybe hoping that Canadians trust you is your best option.

answers.answer: The structure was to make sure that Canadian pensioners could get the most benefit.
answers.feedback: This response leaves people scratching their heads.

answers.answer: I will be releasing a detailed plan on how we will close tax loopholes and ensure everyone pays their fair share.
answers.feedback: This concrete response helps lessen the blow.

question: [April 2025] Healthcare is always an important issue in Canadian elections. How will you manage healthcare if elected?

answers.answer: We need more doctors and more nurses; I will push for licensing reform to allow medical professionals to practice anywhere in Canada and make it easier for those with foreign credentials to become licensed. I will protect existing healthcare programs and will continue to expand the national dental care program.
answers.feedback: This is what your supporters want to hear.

answers.answer: The cost of healthcare is increasing at an unsustainable rate. We need to come up with innovative solutions to bring down costs, including digitization and AI doctors.
answers.feedback: Canadians are worried that these solutions may compromise quality of care.

answers.answer: We need to invest more into our healthcare system. Procedure wait times are unacceptably high, and I will be laser focused on bringing them down.
answers.feedback: This garners some support, but others are worried about how this will be paid for.

answers.answer: Healthcare is a provincial issue, and I will respect their jurisdiction. I will maintain provincial health transfers and work collaboratively with the premiers to find improvements.
answers.feedback: This is a moderate position, though it draws some criticism for its passiveness.

question: [April 2025] Crime is on the minds of many voters, with some losing faith in the justice system. What will you emphasize?

answers.answer: I will cite the statistics that indicate that crime rates are low compared to the historic average. We remain a safe country.
answers.feedback: Dismissing the concerns of voters won;t get them to vote for you.

answers.answer: We need to expand police powers to crack down on crime. For example, police should be authorized to search mail with a general warrant. We should also increase penalties for some crimes.
answers.feedback: This pleases some tough-on-crime voters, but most of them are looking for a much tougher crackdown.

answers.answer: You can't be tough on crime if you're not tough on guns. We need to continue with the gun buyback program and strengthen border enforcement to prevent guns from entering our country.
answers.feedback: By shifting the discussion to gun control, you contrast yourself favourably against the Conservatives. However, some policy wonks do criticize the buyback program as ineffective.

answers.answer: We need to tackle the root causes of crime. The affordability crisis is hard on everyone, but particularly harms those on the margins of society. We need stronger support for the most vulnerable to prevent them from resorting to crime.
answers.feedback: This could be a convincing argument, but many blame the nearly 10 years of Liberal governance for the affordability crisis.

question: [April 2025] As the campaign approaches its midpoint, where will you focus your efforts?

answers.answer: Victoria. I will meet with Premier Eby and speak about our shared priorities.
Hamilton and Niagara Falls. I will speak about how I will protect their manufacturing industries.
Quebec City. I will reiterate my respect for provincial jurisdiction.
Brampton and Scarborough. I will speak to their concerns about crime.

question: [April 2025] Canada has welcomed a record number of immigrants in recent years. What will be your immigration policy?

answers.answer: Canada is an immigrant nation. Our diversity is what makes us strong. We should continue welcoming as many new Canadians as possible and invest into resources to help new immigrants integrate into our communities.
answers.feedback: Many are concerned immigration levels are too high and draw comparisons between you and Trudeau.

answers.answer: The rapid growth of the temporary worker program is concerning considering the allegations of abuse and exploitation. We should restrict this program to address these concerns, instead focusing on welcoming refugees and supporting family reunification.
answers.feedback: This is a noble stand on humanitarian grounds.

answers.answer: Current immigration levels are unsustainable and have put a strain on housing, infrastructure, and public services. I will place a cap on temporary residents and reduce permanent resident admissions to ease that strain.
answers.feedback: This addresses most concerns about immigration, and the issue fades into the background.

answers.answer: We need to reform the system to attract the best talent in the world to build our economy. We should make sure that the immigrants we welcome are net contributors to our society.
answers.feedback: This economic-oriented but vague response maintains a broad appeal.

question: [April 2025] Voters always like a good tax cut. Do you have any plans for tax cuts?

answers.answer: My plan includes a well-deserved tax cut for the middle class, lowering the bottom tax bracket from 15% to 14%.
answers.feedback: This balances cutting taxes with fiscal responsibility.

answers.answer: It's time to let Canadians keep more of what they earn. I will drop the bottom tax bracket to 12.75%.
answers.feedback: The bigger the tax cut, the better. Right?

answers.answer: We don't need any tax cuts right now. We're heading into difficult times with the Trump tariffs, and we should use that money to support people who may lose their jobs from the economic disruption.
answers.feedback: Workers in threatened industries like aluminium, steel, and forestry are happy with your support, but others are disappointed.

answers.answer: I will raise the basic personal allowance to $19,500 and remove GST from essentials like energy bills.
answers.feedback: This helps tie in the tax cuts to the cost-of-living.

question: [April 2025] Housing has become increasingly expensive and is now out of reach for average Canadians. What is your approach to housing?

answers.answer: Housing is a provincial responsibility. I am calling on the Premiers to step up and find solutions on this issue.
answers.feedback: Offering no solutions to a leading issue wins you no favours.

answers.answer: We have a massive housing shortage. We need to throw everything we can at this issue, including working with municipalities to relax zoning bylaws, investing to catalyze the private sector into action, exploring ways to increase construction productivity such as modular housing, and cutting the tax burden on home builders.
answers.feedback: These commitments to tackling the housing crisis make many young people give you another look.

answers.answer: The housing market is too distorted to operate efficiently. We need to remove burdensome regulations, speed up approvals, cut taxes on home building, and slash development charges. These reforms will unleash private investment and make the housing market function properly once again.
answers.feedback: This market approach appeals to some, but many have lost faith that the market can bring affordability on its own.

answers.answer: Building more housing is not enough if the houses are not affordable. We need to lead the charge with large public investments into deeply affordable homes. We need to restrict foreign and corporate ownership of housing and provide stronger support for renters.
answers.feedback: This appeals to low-income renters, but middle class families feel overlooked.

question: [April 2025] Many are concerned with the size of the federal government debt. What will be your fiscal approach?

answers.answer: Spend less, invest more. I will emphasize making a distinction between operating and capital budgets, and pledge to balance the operating budget by the end of my term.
answers.feedback: This gives you room to maneuver in making large investments while still making a clear commitment to financial responsibility.

answers.answer: I will balance the operating budget by the end of the first year in office without any new taxes by making the government more efficient.
answers.feedback: Analysts lambast your plans as infeasible. Voters are worried that this will require extensive cuts to public services.

answers.answer: I will focus on making investments that will grow the economy, allowing us to balance the budget without service cuts.
answers.feedback: The media point out that this sounds awfully similar to the infamous Trudeau line that "the budget will balance itself".

answers.answer: I will both balance the budget and protect the funding of our public services. This will be made possible by a wealth tax on the ultra-wealthy, increased taxes on the profits of large corporations, and cracking down on tax evasion.
answers.feedback: This is a left-wing position that would be more at home in the NDP. It spooks the business community, with some prominent names coming out publicly in opposition to your plans.

question: [April 2025] Israel and Palestine continue to show up in headlines. What will you say on the issue?

answers.answer: What Israel is doing in Gaza is a genocide. We should be putting maximum pressure on the Israeli government to reach a permanent ceasefire and end their illegal occupation of Palestinian land.
answers.feedback: Pro-Palestine organizations are happy with your support, but you face loud accusations of anti-semitism.

answers.answer: Israel must allow humanitarian aid to enter Gaza. I support an arms embargo and will work with our international partners to work towards a two-state solution.
answers.feedback: This is a standard, moderate response on the issue.

answers.answer: This is a far away issue that should not be of interest to Canadians. We have far more important issues to focus on, such as affordability and the economy.
answers.feedback: This angers those who believe the events in Gaza constitute genocide.

answers.answer: Israel has a right to defend itself. As the only democracy in the Middle East, its neighbours are a constant threat to it. To the Israeli people, I stand with you.
answers.feedback: Israel has become increasingly unpopular among Canadians. Standing with them makes you seem out of touch.

question: [April 2025] Oil is a major Canadian export and a major industry in the Western provinces. Would you support the construction of additional pipelines?

answers.answer: Yes. I will work with the provinces and First Nations to simplify the approval process and use emergency powers to streamline the federal side of that equation.
answers.feedback: This satisfies both jurisdictional concerns and oil-producing regions; desire to expand their exports.

answers.answer: We need to focus on building up our LNG infrastructure, and that includes gas pipelines. LNG poses no spill risk and burns clean.
answers.feedback: This satisfies some, but the lack of mention of heavy oil makes others doubt your commitment to the energy sector.

answers.answer: I do not support new pipelines. The Trans Mountain pipeline remains below capacity. The world is shifting away from oil and gas, making a new pipeline an imprudent investment. We should be focusing on becoming a clean energy superpower.
answers.feedback: Environmentalists are ecstatic. Oil workers and dependent communities are furious.

answers.answer: We need to do everything we can to expand the market access for our oil. This is an urgent matter of national and economic security. I will do everything in my power to get these projects moving immediately.
answers.feedback: This satisfies oil-producing regions but raises concerns for some that a pipeline will be forced through their communities.

question: [April 2025] What is your plan for the Canadian Armed Forces?

answers.answer: Every dollar spent on weapons is a dollar not spent to invest into our economy. I will ensure the military has the necessary capabilities for our defence but no more.
answers.feedback: With escalating global tensions, Canadians want to see more investment in the military.

answers.answer: I will fund investments into our armed forces, including raising soldiers' pay and securing the Arctic. This will grow the military budget to 2% of GDP by 2030.
answers.feedback: This is a sensible plan and one that Canadians support.

answers.answer: We live in an increasingly dangerous world. We need large investments into the military, including 3.5% of GDP for personnel and procurement and an additional 1.5% of GDP for building infrastructure to support our troops from coast to coast to coast.
answers.feedback: It;s good to be ambitious, but this represents tripling the military budget which goes a little far for some.

answers.answer: With the threats from down south, it has become clear that we must become more self-reliant for our defence. I will cancel our participation in the F-35 program and launch a review of all procurement agreements with the US. We will aim to maximize domestic procurement and cooperate with the ReArm Europe plan.
answers.feedback: This ruffles some feathers in the US and triggers a Trump rant. This move helps bolster your anti-American credentials.

question: [April 2025] The public service has grown substantially over recent years and has been targeted by the Conservatives. How will you address this?

answers.answer: I will attack the Conservatives for their plans to cut the public service while quietly including similar cuts in my fiscal plan.
answers.feedback: Your gambit works. Public servants flock to your campaign as they fear a Poilievre government, and the size of the cuts in your own plans go unquestioned.

answers.answer: The public service has been growing too quickly. I will slow the growth of the public sector, and improve productivity through the use of AI.
answers.feedback: Your emphasis on AI is certainly ambitious.

answers.answer: I will defend the public service. These are hard-working men and women who help deliver the programs that millions of Canadians depend upon. Instead of outsourcing work to contractors, I will shift the work back to our civil servants. Let there be no doubt that the Conservatives will worsen service and cut essential programs.
answers.feedback: Public servants are happy with your support, but many Canadians do think the public service has grown too large and costly.

answers.answer: We need to spend less and invest more. I will introduce large cuts to the government bureaucracy, freeing up funds to catalyze private investment and economic growth.
answers.feedback: Your position is similar to that of the Conservatives. The NDP attacks both of you harshly, and public servants give them another look.

question: [April 2025] Two official leaders' debates are held, one in French and one in English. What is your strategy going into the debates?

answers.answer: I'll take the fight to Poilievre. I will hammer him on his populist approach to politics and compare him with Donald Trump.
answers.feedback: Poilievre outmaneuvers you and hammers the rise in cost-of-living during the last decade of Liberal governance.

answers.answer: I will stay cool and collected, focusing on fending off attacks from my opponents.
answers.feedback: You start off a little nervous, but you hold your own and get in a few zingers.

answers.answer: I will use the debate as a platform to communicate my economic plan. I don't just talk; I have a strong record for managing economies.
answers.feedback: Your long detailed answers delivered in your monotone voice fail to capture the imagination of Canadians.

answers.answer: I will make a full-throated defense of our valued social programs. From childcare, to dentalcare, to pharmacare, we Liberals have built a more equal and fair society.
answers.feedback: Poilievre ties you with the Trudeau government, he is considered to have won the debates.

question: [April 2025] As the election nears its conclusion, where will you focus your campaign appearances?

answers.answer: I will focus my efforts broadly across the country.
I will campaign in Edmonton, Calgary, and Saskatoon. Alberta and Saskatchewan may be conservative provinces, but we have a chance for a breakthrough in the cities.
I will campaign in the Maritimes. This region is rich in seats for its population, and we need to lock them down.
The Greater Toronto Area. The suburbs are always in contention.

question: [April 2025] It's two days before election day, and a deadly attack on a Filipino street festival in Vancouver has left 11 dead and dozens injured. How do you react?

answers.answer: I will cancel my campaign events and fly to Vancouver to offer my condolences to the victims and their families.
answers.feedback: This is a standard, non-political response to a tragedy like this.

answers.answer: I will call for stronger gun control to prevent attacks like these. If even one such event can be prevented, we have a responsibility to act.
answers.feedback: It was a vehicle-ramming attack, not a shooting. You are criticized for blatantly politicizing the situation.

answers.answer: We need more funds for mental health care to prevent tragedies like this from occurring.
answers.feedback: The culprit was already under mental health supervision with no indication of being a public safety risk.

answers.answer: The culprit was known to police. He should have been locked up before he could cause so much harm.
answers.feedback: He was also never previously charged with any crime. Your comment draws the ire of civil rights groups.

question: [April 2025] It is the day before the election. What is your final message to Canadians?

answers.answer: This election is a decision between unity and division. Between hope and fear. Between building up and tearing down. The future of Canada is at stake.
answers.feedback: Good luck!

answers.answer: We don't need chaos, we need calm. We don't need anger, we need an adult, and we need action. Because we need to fight, we need to protect, and we need to build. Elbows up!
answers.feedback: Good luck!

answers.answer: Pierre Poilievre's war on "woke" is dangerous and has no place in Canada. He is stoking fears and resentment, entrenching division, and legitimizing extreme positions. We need to send a message that this divisive American messaging is not welcome here.
answers.feedback: Good luck!

answers.answer: Your dreams are the same as mine. A country that is safe, where people are kind to each other and get along, where everyone has a place to call home, and people can be who they want to be. Our children should be able to dream about a positive future, not worry about an economic crisis. With everyone pulling together, we will emerge stronger.
answers.feedback: Good luck!
